column1: Would you like to continue to finish this survey?
column2: How long have you been programming?
column3: How long have you participated (in any way) in Open Source Software (OSS)?
column4:
Please indicate your level of agreement with the following statement:


"I pay attention to the 'Why' information when writing commit messages."
column5:
Please indicate your level of agreement with the following statement: 

"I pay attention to the 'What' information when writing commit messages."
column6: Do you think the quality of previous commit messages written by others has any impact on the code change that you commit?
column7: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "Why" information in commit messages: - Other developers may not fully/correctly understand the code changes made in the commits
column8: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "Why" information in commit messages: - The maintainability of the software will be hampered
column9: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "Why" information in commit messages: - The readability/understandability of the entire code base will be reduced
column10: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "Why" information in commit messages: - The software's handover in the future will be more difficult
column11: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "Why" information in commit messages: - There is no impact
column12: If you believe there are other impacts of not having "Why" information in commit message, please briefly describe:
column13: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "What" information in commit messages: - Other developers may not fully/correctly understand the code changes made in the commits
column14: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "What" information in commit messages: - The maintainability of the software will be hampered
column15: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "What" information in commit messages: - The readability/understandability of the entire code base will be reduced
column16: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "What" information in commit messages: - The software's handover in the future will be more difficult
column17: Please identify the potential impacts of not having "What" information in commit messages: - There is no impact
column18: If you believe there are other impacts of not having "What" information in commit message, please briefly describe:
column19: Do you think "Good" commit message is important in ensuring software quality?
column20: Which type of information in commit messages do you think is more important in preventing bugs? - Selected Choice
column21: Which type of information in commit messages do you think is more important in preventing bugs? - Other, please specify: - Text
column22:
Researchers have found that some developers include "Why" information in commit messages by providing an issue report/pull request link.

Do you think itâ€™s a good practice to attach issue report/pull request links to commit messages (instead of directly writing texts) to include "Why" information?
column23:
Please indicate your level of agreement with the following statement:

"When I see a commit message with an issue report/pull request link, and this commit message does not seem to have 'Why', I would always expect to get additional information in the link."
column24: Are you aware of any guidelines about writing "Good" commit messages? - Selected Choice
column25: Are you aware of any guidelines about writing "Good" commit messages? - Yes, please specify: (e.g. links, documents...) - Text
column26: In addition to it containing "What" and "Why", what other aspects do you think are also important to writing a "Good" commit message? Select all that apply - Selected Choice
column27: In addition to it containing "What" and "Why", what other aspects do you think are also important to writing a "Good" commit message? Select all that apply - Other, please specify: - Text

column32: Please briefly describe the reasons for selecting the choices of the previous 2 questions:

column31: If the 'what' is implied by the 'why' (e.g. if I fixed a bug where a null pointer exception was thrown because a field was not initialized), I will omit the 'what'
column32: The first line of the message should always be the 'why'. The 'why' is useful to everyone (future developers, users); the 'what' can often be inferred from the 'why' and the code changes, if not, include the 'what'

column32: I emphasize why, but typically to explain the why you have to summarize the what. I avoid going in-depth on what because to see the in-depth they should look at the code. **Just as important for writing a commit message is keeping the commit contained to a single logical changeset... ie, don't have massive commits that put too many things into one commit**

column12: I want to be clear...all of the work I do with software involves hosted source control management systems like BitBucket or GitHub. I do expect commits to link to prior discussions on those platforns, like pull requests,and that those discussions provide a clear "why" for code changes. That's why I've said here that I don't think including "why" information in commit messages itself is important.

column32: When you need to dive into commit history, it usually means that you either search for some older version of the code or you debug. "Why" needs a lot of context, and "What" gives you more information on what was done.

column32: Why commit messages are not suited for "Whys": "Whys" usually pass through multiple stages before they get agreed upon by the team (design -> request for comments -> approval). It would be impossible/awkward to implement using commit messages. If one decides to find an answer to a why question, then they should be iterating over the whole git history.  "Whys" for significant code changes are implemented as Architecture Decision Records (ADR). For subtle changes, "Whys" remain in corresponding tickets.

column32: It is difficult to precisely describe what was changed and I rather focus on writing well readable code which doesn't need further description. On the other hand the reason why the code had to be changed is not always clear from the change itself and it gives context to the change. The context is very important especially when we refactor the code and thinking why it is written this way. The context can/should be also expressed by tests.
